findings.title: Front-running attack affecting the ERC20 Approve function
findings.description: The approve() method overrides current allowance regardless of whether the spender already used it or not, so there is no way to increase or decrease allowance by a certain value atomically unless the token owner is a smart contract, not an account. This can be abused by a token receiver when they try to withdraw certain tokens from the sender's account.

findings.title: Hidden Mint Function
findings.description: Hidden mint functions may increase the amount of tokens in circulation and effect the price of the token.

findings.title: Balance Modifier Function can modify the balance of tokens at other addresses
findings.description: If there is a function for this, the contract owner can have the authority to modify the balance of tokens at other addresses. For example revoke the bought tokens from the holders wallet.

findings.title: Blacklist Function can restrict certain addresses from trading normally
findings.description: If there is a blacklist, some addresses may not be able to trade normally. Example: you buy the token and right after your Wallet getting blacklisted. Like so you will be unable to sell. Honeypot Risk.

findings.title: Whitelist Setting function can cause farming
findings.description: If there is a function for this, Developer can set zero fee or no max wallet size for addresses (for example team wallets can trade without fee. Can cause farming)

findings.title: Honeypot Risk
findings.description: The contract blocks sell transfer from holder wallet. Multiple events may cause honeypot. Trading disabled, extremely high tax.
